issue.title: Update statrs version to 0.16 to avoid future rust incompatibility
issue.body: In Cargo.toml, set statrs = "^0.16.0" so as to avoid incompatibility with future rust versions.

pull_request.title: fix: minimum ndarray version is 0.15
pull_request.body: Closes #556 as I was able to reproduce the build error with `0.14` reported by @jakobnissen

repo.name: rust-bio
repo.description: This library provides implementations of many algorithms and data structures that are useful for bioinformatics. All provided implementations are rigorously tested via continuous integration.

issue.title: Compat error with array depencency
issue.body:
When compiling `bio`, I get this error:
```
    Checking bio v1.4.0
error[E0277]: `usize` is not an iterator
   --> /home/jakob/.cargo/registry/src/index.crates.io-6f17d22bba15001f/bio-1.4.0/src/pattern_matching/pssm/mod.rs:299:20
    |
299 |         for row in scores.rows() {
    |                    ^^^^^^^^^^^^^ `usize` is not an iterator
    |
    = help: the trait `Iterator` is not implemented for `usize`
    = note: if you want to iterate between `start` until a value `end`, use the exclusive range syntax `start..end` or the inclusive range syntax `start..=end`
    = note: required for `usize` to implement `IntoIterator`

For more information about this error, try `rustc --explain E0277`.
error: could not compile `bio` (lib) due to previous error
```
Which I believe stems from `scores.rows()` now returning `usize` not a view of rows.

comment.body:
I believe I have tracked this down. My project uses `ndarray 0.14.0`, which is specified as compatible with rust-bio, but where this method indeed returns `usize`.
So, the issue is indeed likely to be a compat error - rust-bio actually assumes ndarray 0.15

comment.body: I was able to compile it just now. Which OS and rust version are you using? The minimum rust version for v1.4.0 is 1.65.0

issue.title: Coverage CI test failing due to compiler bug (being addressed upstream)
issue.body:
This is just a tracking issue to report that the cause for the current `Coverage` step failures of the GitHub Actions workflow is being followed up. This can be closed once the respective rust nightly compiler bug is resolved.

I originally [filed a bug over at `rust`](https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/113530) based on [the testing failure in this unrelated PR](https://github.com/rust-bio/rust-bio/pull/542#issuecomment-1628647484). This was found to be a duplicate of [this issue that nicely tracks progress on addressing this bug](https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/113500).

comment.body:
Once this is fixed upstream, we should revert #557. In that PR, @johanneskoester identified this RFC as a more thorough solution:
https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/86656

pull_request.title: fix: Expand path variables when reading `fasta` files
pull_request.body:
I noticed recently that the `fasta::Reader::from_file` interface, my tests were failing if I used path variables (e.g. `$HOME/path/to/file.fasta`). Switching to the full expanded path resolved my issue.

#### I added two small changes to the crate:
1) A new `utils::io` module that includes the `expand_path` function, and
2) the `fasta::Reader` interface should now leverage this to expand out env variables if passed by users.

Let me know what the protocol is for contributing. Thanks!

issue.title: fix: Expand path variables when reading `fasta` files
issue.body:
I noticed recently that the `fasta::Reader::from_file` interface, my tests were failing if I used path variables (e.g. `$HOME/path/to/file.fasta`). Switching to the full expanded path resolved my issue.

#### I added two small changes to the crate:
1) A new `utils::io` module that includes the `expand_path` function, and
2) the `fasta::Reader` interface should now leverage this to expand out env variables if passed by users.

Let me know what the protocol is for contributing. Thanks!

comment.body: Agreed. THis should rather happen outside of rust-bio.

issue.title: feat: Blastn with http request
issue.body:
Implemented a new module where a blast of nucleotides can be done with just a nucleotide strand.
This search is made with the NCBI API with "reqwest" rust library.
Also, transcription, translation, uni to three protein code, and Text format to FASTA format, was implemented as the main blast module.

comment.body: And thanks a lot for the contribution!

pull_request.title: chore: temporarily disable coverage estimation until simd support has arrived in the stable rust stdlib
pull_request.body: This is because our current simd dependency has become incompatible with nightly rust.
